rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you.

|align=center|
|'''[[Vladimir Obruchev]]'''<br> (1863â1956)<br>{{flag|Russian Empire}}<br>{{flag|Soviet Union}}<small><br><br>'''[[geologist]], geographer, explorer of [[Siberia]] and [[Central Asia]], [[science fiction]] author'''<br><br>(portrait on the cover of Obruchev's memoirs ''Digging for [[Pluto (mythology)|Pluto]]'s Secrets'')</small>
|'''[[Vladimir Obruchev]]'''<br> (1863â1956)<br>{{flag|Russian Empire}}<br>{{flag|Soviet Union}}<small><br><br>'''[[geologist]], geographer, explorer of [[Siberia]] and [[Central Asia]], [[science fiction]] author'''<br><br>(portrait on the cover of Obruchev's memoirs ''Digging for [[Pluto (mythology)|Pluto]]'s Secrets'')</small>
|Having graduated from the [[Petersburg Mining Institute]] in 1886, Obruchev went to [[Siberia]]. He studied gold-mining and assisted in constructing [[Central Asian Railway|Central Asian]] and [[Trans-Siberian Railway]]s. In [[Central Asia]] he '''explored the [[Kara Kum]] Desert, the shores of the [[Amu Darya]] River, and the old riverbeds of the [[Uzbois]]'''. In 1892-94 Obruchev took part in the [[Grigory Potanin]]'s expedition to [[Mongolia]] and [[North China]]. He '''explored the [[Transbaikal]] area, [[Dzhungaria]] and [[Altai Mountains]]'''. Having '''spent half a century in exploring Siberia and Inner Asia''', Obruchev summarized his findings in the extensive work ''The Geology of Siberia''. He studied the origins of [[loess]], the [[ice]] formation and [[permafrost]], and the [[tectonics]] of [[Siberia]]. All together, he authored over a thousand scientific works. Obruchev is also known as '''the author of two popular [[science fiction]] novels, ''[[Hollow Earth|Plutonia]]'' (1915) and ''[[Sannikov Land]]'' (1924)'''. These stories, imitating the pattern of [[Arthur Conan Doyle]]'s ''[[The Lost World (Arthur Conan Doyle)|The Lost World]]'', depict in vivid detail the discovery of an isolated world of prehistoric animals in hitherto unexplored large islands in the [[Arctic]].<ref>[http://archivsf.narod.ru/persona/obruchev/obruchev.htm Obruchev's biography] {{ru icon}}</ref><small><br><br>Obruchevite mineral, Akademik Obruchev Range in [[Tuva]], a mountain near the upper [[Vitim River]], an [[oasis]] in [[Antarctica]], [[Obruchev (crater)|Obruchev crater]] on the [[Moon]], the Obruchev Prize for works in the field of [[Siberia]]n geology, ''Vladimir Obruchev'' oil and gas research vessel and many streets and other places have been named after Obruchev.</small>
|Having graduated from the [[Petersburg Mining Institute]] in 1886, Obruchev went to [[Siberia]]. He studied gold-mining and assisted in constructing [[Central Asian Railway|Central Asian]] and [[Trans-Siberian Railway]]s. In [[Central Asia]] he '''explored the [[Kara Kum]] Desert, the shores of the [[Amu Darya]] River, and the old riverbeds of the [[Uzbois]]'''. In 1892-94 Obruchev took part in the [[Grigory Potanin]]'s expedition to [[Mongolia]] and [[North China]]. He '''explored the [[Transbaikal]] area, [[Dzhungaria]] and [[Altai Mountains]]'''. Having '''spent half a century in exploring Siberia and Inner Asia''', Obruchev summarized his findings in the extensive work ''The Geology of Siberia''. He studied the origins of [[loess]], the [[ice]] formation and [[permafrost]], and the [[tectonics]] of [[Siberia]]. All together, he authored over a thousand scientific works. Obruchev is also known as '''the author of two popular [[science fiction]] novels, ''[[Hollow Earth|Plutonia]]'' (1915) and ''[[Sannikov Land]]'' (1924)'''. These stories, imitating the pattern of [[Arthur Conan Doyle]]'s ''[[The Lost World (Arthur Conan Doyle)|The Lost World]]'', depict in vivid detail the discovery of an isolated world of prehistoric animals in hitherto unexplored large islands in the [[Arctic]].<ref>[http://archivsf.narod.ru/persona/obruchev/obruchev.htm Obruchev's biography] {{ru icon}}</ref><small><br><br>Obruchevite mineral, Akademik Obruchev Range in [[Tuva]], a mountain near the upper [[Vitim River]], an [[oasis]] in [[Antarctica]], [[Obruchev (crater)|Obruchev crater]] on the [[Moon]], the Obruchev Prize for works in the field of [[Siberia]]n geology, ''Vladimir Obruchev'' oil and gas research vessel and many streets and other places have been named after Obruchev.</small>
